subject: thoughts to live by
verse: And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love Him, who have been called according to His purpose. (Ro. 8:28) NIV
reflection: God works in "everything" not just isolated incidents for our good. This does not mean that all that happens to us is good. Evil is prevalent in our fallen world, but God is able to turn every circumstance around for our long-range good. We need to note that God is not always working to make us happy but to fulfill His purpose. We also should note that this promise is not for everyone. It can only be claimed by those who love God, and are called by Him, that is, those whom the Holy Spirit convinces to receive Christ. Such people have a new perspective, a new mind-set. They trust in God, not in worldly treasures; their security is in heaven, not on earth. Their faith in God does not waver in pain and persecution because they know God is with them.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father of all mercy and grace, the creator of all things, keep our nation, its citizens, and our troops safe from all harm. Bless my e-mail friends with good health and safety. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: For those God foreknew He also predestined to be conformed to the likeness of His Son, that He might be the firstborn among many brothers. And those He predestined, He also called; those He called he also justified; Those He justified, He also glorified. (Ro. 8:29, 30) NIV.
reflection: God's ultimate goal for us is to make us like Christ (I Jn. 3:2). As we become more and more like Him, we will discover our true selves, the person we were created to be. How can we become like Christ? By reading and heeding the Word, by studding His life on earth through the Gospels, by spending time in prayer, by being filled with His Spirit, and by doing His work in the world.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? Shall trouble or hardship or persecution or famine or nakedness or danger or sword? As it is written: "For Your sake we face death all day long; we are considered as sheep to be slaughtered." (Ro. 8:35, 36) NIV
reflection: These words were written to a church which would soon undergo terrible persecution. In just a few years, Paul's hypothetical situations would turn into painful realities. But this passage also reaffirms God's profound love for His people. No matter what happens to us, no matter where we are, we can never be separated from His love. Suffering should not drive us away from God but help us to identify with Him and allow His love to heal us.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, our Protector, Provider, and Redeemer, I thank You, that You are always near to protect, provide and save me from the wiles of Satan. Instill in me a sensitivity to the dangers of temptation. Help me to have a closer walk with Thee. Amen.

verse: No, in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us. For I am convinced that neither death nor life, neither angels, nor demons, neither the present nor the future, nor any powers, neither height nor depth, nor anything else in all creation, will be able to separate us from the love of God that is in Christ Jesus our Lord. (Ro. 8:37-39) NIV
reflection: These verse contain one of the most comforting promises in all the Scriptures. Believers have always needed to face hardships in many forms: Persecution, illness, imprisonment, and yes even death. But of course this sometimes cause believers to think they have been abandoned by Christ. But Paul says: "This is impossible." He says it is impossible to be separated from Christ. How can we be sure of this? ~~ Christ's death for us is proof of His unconquerable love. Nothing, can separate us from Christ's presence. God tells us how great His love is so that we will feel totally secure in Him. If we believe these overwhelming assurances, we will not be afraid.
prayer: Dear heavenly Father, I thank You for this wonderful promise. I thank You for the assurance that nothing can separate me from the presence of Jesus Christ. I thank You for Your love. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: I Speak the truth in Christ~~~I am not lying, my conscience confirms it in the Holy Spirit, I have great sorrow and unceasing anguish in my heart. For I could wish that I myself were cursed and cut off from Christ for the sake of my brothers, those of my own race. (Ro. 9:1-3)
reflection: Here Is What We Should Learn From These Verses: We see that Paul expresses concern for his Jewish "brothers and sisters" by saying that he would willingly take their punishment if that would save them. Now we need to remember, Christ is the only one who can save us. Paul shared a rare depth of love. Like Jesus he was willing to sacrifice so others would be saved. How concerned are you for those who do not know Christ? Are you willing to sacrifice your time, money, energy, comfort, and safety to see them come to faith in Jesus?
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, forgive me for not showing the concern I should for the lost. Instill in me a genuine concern for all who are walking in darkness. Amen.

verse: When Paul mentioned the people of "his own race" he was referring to the people of Israel. Theirs is the adoption as sons; theirs the divine glory, the covenants, the receiving of the law, the temple worship and the promises. Theirs are the patriarchs, and from them is traced the human ancestry of Christ, who is God over all, forever praised! Amen. (Ro. 9:4, 5) NIV
reflection: What we should always remember is, that the Jews are God's chosen people. The Jews viewed God's choosing of Israel in the Old Testament as being like adoption. They were undeserving and without rights as natural children~~ Yet God adopted them and granted them the status of His sons and daughters. But lets also remember (2 Cor. 5:17, 18) Therefore if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation; the old has gone, and the new has come! All this is from God who reconciled us to Himself through Christ and gave us the ministry of reconciliation. Those who accept Christ, and become Christians have become new people on the inside~~The Holy Spirit gives them new life, and they are not the same anymore. They are re-created (new creations) living in vital union with Christ (Co. 2:6, 7).
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I know that I am undeserving of being called your child, but I do believe in the finished work of Christ on the cross thus making me a new creature. I thank You also for the work of the Holy Spirit which gives new life so that I can be reconciled to You. I thank You for the union with Christ that is so vital in my life. Amen.

verse: Paul writes: Not by works but by Him who calls ~ Rebekah was told, "The older will serve the younger. Just as it is written: "Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated." What then shall we say? Is God unjust? Not at all! For He says to Moses, "I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and will have compassion on whom I have compassion. (Ro. 9:12-15) NIV
reflection: The Lesson to be Learned: Was it right for God to choose Jacob, the younger, to be over Esau? In Malachi 1:2, 3, the statement "I showed my love for you by loving your ancestor Jacob. Yet Esau was Jacob's brother, and I rejected Esau" this refers to the nation of Israel and Edom rather than the individual brothers. God chose Jacob to continue the family line of the faithful because He knew his heart was for God. BUT He did not exclude Esau from knowing and loving Him. We need to keep in mind the kind of God we worship: He is sovereign; He is not arbitary; in all things He works for our good; He is trustworthy; He will save all who believe in Him. When we understand these qualities of God, we know that His choices are good even if we do not understand all His reasons.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I surely don't understand all that You do, for if I did You would not be God. But I do accept Your reasoning by faith seeking to follow You daily. Forgive me when I stumble. Amen.

verse: One of you will say to me, Then why does God still blame? For who resists His will? But who are you, O man, to talk back to God? Shall what is formed say to Him who formed it, 'Why did You make me like this? Does not the potter have the right to make out of the same lump of clay some pottery for noble purposes and some for common use? (Romans 9:19)
reflection: With this illustration, Paul is not saying that some of us are worth more than others, but that the Creator has control over the created object. The created object, therefore, has no right to demand anything from its Creator~~its very existence depends on Him. Keeping this perspective removes any temptation to have pride in any personal achievement.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, forgive me for complying that others have far more talent than I. I should be very thankful for the gifts You have given me. If I were to truly examine my life I would have to confess that I have so much to be thankful for. Thank You Lord for those blessings. Amen.

these, the natural branches be grafted into there own olive tree! (Ro. 11:22-24) NIV

What We Should Glean From This:

To "continue to trust in His kindness" refers to steadfast perseverance in faith...

Steadfastness is a proof of the reality of faith and by-product of salvation ~~
not a means to it...

Our Prayer for Today:
Dear Heavenly Father, I thank You for Your loving-kindness.
Help me to remain steadfast in trust and faith in You. Help
me to have a Christ-like love for all man-kind. Help me to
be a better witness for You...Amen.

Keep looking up, He cares for you...
You are in the prayers of two who care...
Pastor Al & Marcie Sather

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: I don't want you to be ignorant of this mystery, brothers, so that you may not be conceited: Israel has experienced a hardening in part until the full number of Gentiles has come in. And so all Israel will be saved, as it is written: "The deliver will come from Zion; He will turn godlessness away from Jacob. (Romans 11:25)
reflection: Some say the phrase "and so all Israel will be saved" means that the majority of the Jew in the final generation before Christ's return will turn to Christ for salvation. Others say that Paul is using the term Israel to refer to the "Spiritual" nation of Israel, which is comprised of Jews and Gentiles who have received salvation through faith in Christ. AND so, "all Israel" (or all believers) will receive God's promised gift of salvation. Still others say that "all Israel" means Israel as a whole will have a role in Christ's Kingdom. The Jews' identity as a people won't be discarded. God chose the nation of Israel, and He has never rejected it. He also chose the church, through Jesus Christ and He will never reject it either. This does not mean, of course, that all Jews or all church members will be saved. It is possible to be Jewish or to belong to a church without ever responding in faith. But just because some people have rejected Christ does not mean that God stops working with either Israel or the church. He continues to offer salvation freely to all. Still others say that the phrase "and so" means "in this way" or "this is how, " referring to the necessity of faith in Christ.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, Give me wisdom to sort out the truth about salvation, that I would glean from Your Word Your will. Open my heart that I may see glimpses of truth You have for me. Amen.
